user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 sem_initial_value, uint32 options)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_initial_value > SEM_VALUE_MAX)
    {
        return OS_INVALID_SEM_VALUE;
    }

    if (sem_init(&impl->id, 0, sem_initial_value) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemCreate_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_INVALID_SEM_VALUE (-20)
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The code does not call any <string.h> functions (memcpy, strcpy, strlen, etc.), so fragments involving sem_init and the sem value check are not relevant to MISRA C Rule 21.17. The sem_initial_value check and the sem_t field in the record do not involve character buffers or string operations and therefore do not create string.h out-of-bounds risks. The struct definition (only contains sem_t id) and the error-code macros are unrelated to string handling and need not be investigated for Rule 21.17.

The listed suspicious fragments are those that perform pointer dereference and array indexing using token->obj_idx (the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro, its use, the table definition, and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken). These should be investigated because an invalid or out-of-range obj_idx or a NULL/invalid token could cause indexing outside OS_impl_count_sem_table, which is the kind of out-of-bounds access that must be checked when string functions operate on such objects elsewhere.
